title: How to Cook West African White Soup and Pounded Yam

steps.headline: Wash and boil the meat.
steps.description: Whether it is goat or chicken meat, spice it up with onion, pepper, salt and any other seasonings of your choice.

steps.headline: Remember not to add water at first until it releases its own juices as it boils.
Ensure that the meat is soft and tasty before finishing the cooking.
Slice the yam, wash and boil.
As the yam boils, wash the pepper, leaves, stock, fish head and smoked fish.
Put the stock fish head into hot water to make it soft.
steps.description: This makes it easier to divide.

steps.headline: Pound or blend crayfish and pepper together.
Check to see whether the yam is soft before removing it from the water.
steps.description: Place it into the yam pounder. If a yam pounder is not available, then use a mortar and pestle. Put the yam in when extremely hot; this assists when trying to blend the yam and will ensure smoothness and elasticity. The yam might be sticky; if so, you add cold water but if it is not sticky at all, add hot water.

steps.headline: Try to ensure that the pounded yam doesn't contain any balls and that it is smooth.
Check that it has formed a paste-like consistency.
steps.description: When it is in a paste form, remove and transfer to a warmer. Keep it warm before serving.

steps.headline: Using the meat stock you prepared earlier, boil it.
steps.description: When bubbling, add the pounded or blended crayfish and pepper.

steps.headline: Add the stock fish head and smoked fish.
Cover the pot and wait to for it to boil.
Add shredded yam.
steps.description: When bubbling, open the flask, the one with the pounded yam, scoop out an ample amount, then shred it to pieces and put in the pot. It serves as a thickener to thicken the soup. Ensure that the pot is left open and not closed, as it helps to thicken the soup faster. If the soup is too thick, remove some of the shredded yam in it. If it is too loose, add more shredded yam.

steps.headline: Taste to ensure how tasty it is.
steps.description: When the soup is thick enough, ensure that it is to your taste. You can add seasonings, such as salt, Maggi flavor sachets or other seasonings you like.

steps.headline: Add the shredded leaves last.
steps.description: Don't keep the leaves on the fire too long.

text: Preparation Wash and boil the meat. Whether it is goat or chicken meat, spice it up with onion, pepper, salt and any other seasonings of your choice. Remember not to add water at first until it releases its own juices as it boils.  Ensure that the meat is soft and tasty before finishing the cooking.  Slice the yam, wash and boil. Do not add any salt. As the yam boils, wash the pepper, leaves, stock, fish head and smoked fish.  Put the stock fish head into hot water to make it soft. This makes it easier to divide. Pound or blend crayfish and pepper together.  Shred the uziza/adusa leaves.  Pounding the yam Check to see whether the yam is soft before removing it from the water. Place it into the yam pounder. If a yam pounder is not available, then use a mortar and pestle. Put the yam in when extremely hot; this assists when trying to blend the yam and will ensure smoothness and elasticity. The yam might be sticky; if so, you add cold water but if it is not sticky at all, add hot water. Try to ensure that the pounded yam doesn't contain any balls and that it is smooth.  Check that it has formed a paste-like consistency. When it is in a paste form, remove and transfer to a warmer. Keep it warm before serving. Cooking the soup Using the meat stock you prepared earlier, boil it. When bubbling, add the pounded or blended crayfish and pepper. Add the stock fish head and smoked fish.  Cover the pot and wait to for it to boil.  Add shredded yam. When bubbling, open the flask, the one with the pounded yam, scoop out an ample amount, then shred it to pieces and put in the pot. It serves as a thickener to thicken the soup. Ensure that the pot is left open and not closed, as it helps to thicken the soup faster. If the soup is too thick, remove some of the shredded yam in it. If it is too loose, add more shredded yam. Taste to ensure how tasty it is. When the soup is thick enough, ensure that it is to your taste. You can add seasonings, such as salt, Maggi flavor sachets or other seasonings you like. Add the shredded leaves last. Don't keep the leaves on the fire too long.
